commentBody:
Congrats to the new graduate!

I loved the puzzle. And was able to get it without looking anything up -- which is the ideal for me but not always possible. 

Also, DINO chicken nuggets taste best.

userDisplayName: Flexibility is the key to deterrence
commentBody: IGIVE and AGAVE form a very nice cross, with their intersection also serving as an answer elsewhere in the puzzle!

My fastest Saturday solve ever (20min)!
Surprisingly easy for a Saturday, but still a fun solve
I wonder how many non-Canadians are going to get 17A quickly.

Quick solve, and enjoyable. This must've been right on my wavelength, because I breezed through it more quickly than most Saturdays.
My thanks to the puzzle-builder.

It's a Prime misdirect when SAMEDAYSHIPPING and 
SAMEDAYDELIVERY fit in the same size boxes.
Broad range of areas tapped, along with sly misdirections created a satisfying puzzle.  A little bit light for a Saturday.

I got this one done quickly for a Saturday, thanks to the plethora of sports references.  I‚Äôm sure non sports fans and especially those from countries other than the US will be less happy with them

I was happy to see Arlo PARKS in the heart of the puzzle.   For one thing it‚Äôs a welcome change from Guthrie as a clue, but also because she‚Äôs a fine young singer.  Her Black Dog (very different from Led Zeppelin‚Äôs Black Dog) is a good introduction to her emotionally intense songwriting.  I was also happy to see one of my favorite classic bands (CCR) make an appearance too.
KIMSCONVENIENCE was one hell of a spanner if you haven't watched the show. Took me a while to work around it before I guessed what it was. 16 minute solve

Found a foothold in the SE and ambled on from there.

Saturdays are my favorite.

Enjoy the weekend!
17A is an unfair clue.
Just the right level of difficulty for a Saturday.  Spot on!
Easy puzzle
Great puzzle, Ryan!  Congratulations on your graduation. Big fan of KIMSCONVENIENCE so that long spanner helped me get a foothold. Loved that it crossed with MINIMART.

Congratulations, Ryan Judge on your college graduation and this wonderful puzzle! What a fun way to mark the occasion. üéäüéì I especially loved DINO shaped chicken nuggets. ‚ù§Ô∏èü¶ñüêì

I hope your next move is law school, so you can one day be Judge Judge! ü§£ (sorry, I can't help it)

I wonder if young Mr. Judge (any relation to Aaron?) is a Mets fan.  First time that ALONSO has been clued to Pete; it's mostly been clued to the king in The Tempest. 

Any puzzle that references the TATE and CCR is okay by me.

However, in my opinion this, puzzle makes the case for the occasional themeless Wednesday that some people have been advocating for.
It took me two-thirds the time of my average Wednesday time to solve.  It may have been because a lot of it was in my wheelhouse, but I'm really not that good a Saturday solver.

Congratulations on your graduation, Mr. Judge, and best wishes for your future endeavors!

I enjoyed your breezy puzzle and hope to see you back here soon.
Ironically, my best friend‚Äôs son is graduating from the school originally founded as the Medical College of Louisiana this week, so that was a gimme today interesting puzzle

Well, here's one for the books - hope it helps any solver who ends up in the wordweeds . . .

Thinking in Friday easy solver mode, I put on mental training wheels and rephrased some (most) of those tough clues.

"What might lead to a row at a party?"

After staring at that clue for a looong while, realised staring could be filed under lollygagging, and those white squares loomed large. So, I cut the clue down to size by what I hoped were cogitating on key words and gave 'em a twirl.

Political row? Nope
Boat party? Oars? Nah
Dance?
"Dance in a row?"
Bingo! 

This approach would be futile in a say, 1949 Maleska grid, as any of you who followed that link and tore your hair out might attest to, but it worked like a charm tonight. YMMV

It pains me to admit it took a while for the penny to drop on SAMEDAYDELIVERY, even after that black bird landed under a pseudo food that too may smallfry eatsalot!
Cheeky and cute, but not in an annoying way‚Äîthe best! And weirdly fast for a Saturday, but in a satisfying way‚Äîalso the best!
Good puzzle! Pretty easy for me - 12 minutes. 15A and 41D were punny. Congrats dude!

I have a target time for every day of the week from Monday to Saturday: 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30.  I hit the 15 minute mark for Wed. the most often, and fail most often with Monday and Thursday.  Today was about right: I solved in a little less than 24 minutes, without having to look anything up.  Once I got "Kim's convenience" I solved the rest quickly.  I never saw the show, but it seemed to fit.
I very much enjoyed 41D.  I got the final X before anything else, which greatly helped my mind to go to product names.

For me, and it sounds like several others, the real battle went down in the North East. 

Like others have mentioned - as soon as KIMS CONVENIENCE came to me, the rest went down smooth, but that spanner took me a fair bit of work. I had been playing with KIMS COrnEr‚Ä¶ was trying to make something like ‚Äúcorner store‚Äù fit. 

I had a good time the whole way. Fun puzzle.
Fun puzzle! Not even a quibble per se, but is ‚Äúmescal‚Äù really the NYT‚Äôs preferred spelling of ‚Äúmezcal‚Äù? I‚Äôve worked at agave-focused bars for years and never seen that spelling in my life
I was so psyched when I incorrectly entered Fresh off the Boat. But soon saw it didn‚Äôt work. Great job, Ryan!

"You still competing in hurdles?"
"Oh, I'm so over them."

("That tracks.")

If Sunday Scaries are the feeling you get dreading the work week, I vote Sorrowful Saturday is the feeling you get when you have reached the APEX of the solving week and the Saturday puzzle is behind you ‚òπÔ∏è

Fun fact about the SHERATON in Boston: there's a huge sign on top with the hotel name spelled out in 10 foot tall illuminated white letters. For years during Rush week members of the MIT fraternity ATO would somehow get to the roof of the hotel and turn off all the letters except three. After a while the hotel gave up trying to prevent the sneaky undergrads from breaking in and just changed the sign voluntarily for them each year. No idea if this still happens; I'd be interested to learn!
I assumed the spelling of mezcal as "mescal" was a redirect and started trying things like "cacti", thinking it was referring to mescaline. Guess I need to solve a few more crosswords.

Interesting to see how 17A affects different solvers. I thought the clue was Monday-Tuesday level, comparing it to something like [Sitcom set in a Boston bar run by Sam Malone]. Of course, I know absolutely nothing about Game of Thrones, so I see this as payback for all those DAENERYS and STARK clues I've been clueless about for all these years.

Ended, ere it begun‚Äî
The Title was scarcely told
When the Preface perished from Consciousness
The Story, unrevealed‚Äî

Had it been mine, to print!
Had it been yours, to read!
That it was not Our privilege
The interdict of God‚Äî
--
Hauntingly beautiful, as I find so much of Emily Dickinson's poetry. I've actually been mocked for my fondness of her poetry, which is strange to me, but I remain a big fan. 

And this is my favorite clue for the ever popular ERE that I've encountered in my crosswording time.

As for the puzzle, well, what can I say, I even managed to get the sports references...  

Okay, I only got one without the crosses, RAVENS, again for literary reasons. But the others were very kindly crossed.

Fine and fast overall! Many of my first inclinations were correct, which is a bit unusual for a Saturday. 

I didn't comment on yesterday's puzzle, meaning Friday, but I was very happy to see AGORA. I've been waiting for it since it last appeared in August and I lamented in the comments that when I encounter it, I know it's in my head but I can't pull it out. And a couple of you helped me with a good tip about remembering agoraphobia from fear of the marketplace. I filled it in immediately today! With a huzzah! And a thanks to you more experienced and generous solvers when I essentially asked ANYADVICE?

All the names and trivia... Meh. This was an ideal example of the kind of puzzle that's personally hard for me in the most unenjoyable kind of way - much like last week's Sunday was. Names and abbreviations all around, including at least three sport references. Or maybe four? I have no idea what ACC may be, where Miami is supposed to be.

Cultural references were my undoing, too. SLIMED? I had Nickelodeon on satellite tv in the early 90s. My parents had a satellite dish installed on the tiny balcony of our apartment (with a pirated card in the decoder ü§£; almost nobody here  could afford Western subscriptions then, and they weren't even offered to us Slavic pariahs for years) despite financial difficulties most Poles shared at the time - to let me watch TV in English. However, I never liked Nickelodeon much. There was something about it... I don't know... Uncouth? Boring, nerdy preteen and teen Andrzej preferred Nat Geo, Star Trek on British Sky TV, and the odd bare bosom on late-night German channels. I wasn't popular at school ü§£

My grid is punctuated by the red marks of reveals - once I realized how much arcana there was, I did not even bother to look things up. My few gimmes (ARLO Parks of the angelic voice and moving lyrics; Rita ORA; OMAN) helped little.

Btw. RIDES UP was a gimme, too. For years I struggled with underpants riding up my legs during climbing, and bunching up under the harness. Under Armour Performance underpants were the answer. Highly recommend üëçüèæ
I'd never heard of 17A so that caused problems. Other than that I liked this puzzle.

For this member of the non expat overseas contingent this puzzle was somewhat painful. 

Tractable but crosses did a lot of heavy lifting 

Congratulations to the constructor graduating.
Congrats on your graduation!  Enjoyed the puzzle.
Great puzzle! I trapped myself with ‚Äúghostly‚Äù vs ‚Äúghastly‚Äù and had a very long search to find my mistake, otherwise would have been a Saturday best for me.

KIM‚ÄôS CONVENIENCE has been on my Watch List for a while, so that was a big help in getting me started. Maybe the puzzle is telling me it‚Äôs time to watch it, already!

I spent some time trying to make ‚Äúconga‚Äù-something work in the space that eventually became LINE DANCE. At least I was on the right track.

This was my kind of Saturday: tough enough to be challenging yet accessible enough to finish without lookups, with a few fun facts along the way. Thanks and congrats, college grad!

Two quick things:

1) I second Andrzej's comment on ACC. From the context, I assume the second C must stand for Conference, but have no clue what the full initialism means.

2) My streak hit 365 today!

Ah, the mescal vs. mezcal spelling. Always a good reason to stop and consider the peripatetic orthographies of our (largely) bilingual continent. If only the IPA had been around when Hern√°n Cort√©s (*not* Cortez) was pillaging and plundering young Mexico-to-be while  Spanish chroniclers were MacGyvering their own ad hoc system of transcribing Nahuatl with the Latin alphabet and monastic spelling, er, habits. Just think: They could‚Äôve just preserved mexcalli as /me ÉÀàkalÀêi/ (or something very close to that), then sat back and waited. Presto, a few centuries go by and, poof! the Spanish monks are gone, and we Americans can start spelling /me ÉÀàkalÀêi/ as meshcali as we take the Southwest for ourselves. No messing around with mexcalli/mezcal/mescal and its, er, prickly etymology. Then we just call it mesh‚Äîbecause if there‚Äôs one national trait we all share, it‚Äôs to compulsively abbreviate everything. Obvi. 

Not a bad Saturday, though a quick one. A whole spanner dedicated to a sitcom? That always seems like a wasted opportunity to me, but I‚Äôm shouting into the wind as usual. The SHERATON clue was an interesting bit of trivia. And I just pledged some funds to Pete ALONSO‚Äôs homeless dogs, so thank you for that link, Caitlin. 

One thing caught my eye: that Ryan Judge said he‚Äôs entering adulthood now that he‚Äôs graduating from college. Things change a lot in a generation. I thought my adulthood began with freshman year, crazy as the years that ensued were. Still, all the best to him.

BACHARELADO EM ADMINISTRA√á√ÉO EM HABILITA√á√ÉO EM GEST√ÉO EM AGRONEG√ìCIO DO BRASIL üáßüá∑ AM√âRICA LATINA. BACHAREL FERNANDO CESAR DIAS BRASILEIRO DO BRASIL üáßüá∑ AM√âRICA LATINA. 
ESCRITOR FERNANDO CESAR DIAS BRASILEIRO DO BRASIL üáßüá∑ AM√âRICA LATINA. 
E-BOOK FALANDO COM DEUS ESCRITOR FERNANDO CESAR DIAS BRASILEIRO DO BRASIL üáßüá∑ AM√âRICA LATINA. 
RESUME DO NOVO TESTAMENTO MATHEUS, MARCOS, LUCAS √â JO√ÉO. 
ESCRITO EM TODAS AS L√çNGUAS DO MUNDO üó∫. 
PARA ADQUIRIR UM 1‚É£ FALAR COM EDITORA KELPS DE GOI√ÇNIA ESTADO DE GOI√ÅS BRASIL üáßüá∑ AM√âRICA LATINA.

Unlike others, I didn't find this particularly easy.  The many team sports references, a new to me singer and sitcom, and caNS instead of BINS at 6A made it fall on the tougher side for me.

The most embarrassing error was putting in Mao  instead of MLK.  Don't ask why.  I don't have an answer for that.

All of those snags made for an entertaining solve where I had to buckle down and work with what I know and puzzle out the rest, which is what I like to do.
Slime takes me back... Went down a little YouTube rabbit hole. Didn't remember that Alanis Morissette was in a few episodes of You Can't Do That on Television. Funny.

A little easier than yesterday.  Much easier than Thursday.

Didn't know the sitcom, but got it by intuition after guessing LAKER.  Ditto AGAVE   Had bro ERE ARO.  Was thinking animals, not Samsungs.

For once, actually surprised that so many found this one unusually easy. Typical tough Saturday for me, and did have to cheat a bit in a couple of places. Then just a whole lot of pondering and working the crosses. Still a couple of answers that were completely unfamiliar to me - 17a notably. Some puzzle finds today. Here's one: A Sunday from December 3, 1972 by Elmer Toro with the title: "Wild Life." Seven long theme answers - all of them familiar phrases, but all of them appearing for the first and only time in any puzzle: A couple of theme clue and answer examples: "Blake's vision" TIGERTIGERBURNINGBRIGHT "Start of a certain recipe" EYEOFNEWTANDTOEOFFROG And the other theme answers: ANDLETSLIPTHEDOGSOFWAR WHEREEAGLESDARENOTPERCH QUOTHTHERAVENNEVERMORE SAIDTHESPIDERTOTHEFLY ANDWHETHERPIGSHAVEWINGS Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=12/3/1972&g=94&d=A I'll put the other puzzles in replies. ....

I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs too much of a gripe to say that KIMS CONVENIENCE is a no-doubt fine but very niche North American reference. Apart from a lot of ‚Äòyou either know or you don‚Äôt‚Äô answers crossing it, a fine puzzle for those of any latitude or longitude.

Not the first puzzle where I forgot DINO was the preferred chicken nugget shape. I always default to BOOT or one of the other 3 official McDonald shapes (BONE, BALL, BELL). See item 10 in the link below: https://corporate.mcdonalds.com/corpmcd/our-stories/article/10-things-mcnuggets.html#:~:text=Yes%2C%20they%20really%20do%20come,our%20personal%20favorite%20%E2%80%93%20the%20Boot.

This one triggered lovely side trips, got my brain bouncing all over the place:
‚Ä¢	GHASTLY got me thinking about GH-starting words I love, like ‚Äúgherkin‚Äù and ‚Äúghee‚Äù.
‚Ä¢	Which brought up ‚Äúghoti‚Äù, a tongue-in-cheek spelling for ‚Äúfish‚Äù that I haven‚Äôt thought about in ages, with the ‚Äúgh‚Äù as in ‚Äúenough‚Äù, the ‚Äúo‚Äù as in ‚Äúwomen‚Äù, and the ‚Äúti‚Äù as in words ending in ‚Äútion‚Äù.
‚Ä¢	FROG next to ROCK made me remember the kids show ‚ÄúFraggle Rock‚Äù.
‚Ä¢	Ryan just graduated from Carnegie Mellon, which is in Pittsburgh, which got me picturing scenes from ‚ÄúThe Pitt‚Äù, a riveting series with memorable characters, and just very well done.

Plus, lovely serendipities: ORA touching corners with ARO, RIDES UP abutting FLYING SOUTH, and IGIVE crossing AGAVE (Hi, @Flexibility!).  Not to mention lovely answers ANY ADVICE and SO THAT‚ÄôS THAT, which are both NYT answer debuts.  

Thus, more of a cornucopia than simply a fill-in.  Congratulations on your graduation, Ryan, and thank you for this rich outing!
Fast and fun!
Pretty proud of myself.
Not bad, but way too much sports trivia. The ideal amount being, of course, zero.

Well, the symmetry across the NW-SE diagonal made this one visually interesting, with the two spanning entries (KIMSCONVENIENCE and SAMEDAYDELIVERY) intersecting at the M. Never heard of the former, but the crosses provided most of it, and the expansive clue helped with the rest.

Seemed like another themeless Wednesday-level puzzle to me, with rather bland fill (EATSALOT) and a lot of proper nouns.

Not GHASTLY by any means, but on a scale of ONETOTEN, IGIVE it a KLEENEX.

ARO symmetrically paired with its anadrome ORA is cute.

Do you mean that a team name is not protected?  That ARIzona can steal the sacred STLouis Cards' identity?  Isn't that a felony?

I know ONE rock group:  CCR.  Handy.  
Wait!  Foo Fighters, I know that name too!  But none of their music, SO there's THAT.  

I thought on Saturdays, the NYT would DIAL up the difficulty level, but instead it's just the Junk Factor (SPILL THE TEA, more than one sports team, brank name, obscure or pass√© TV)...  

Eager to see tomorrow's Big Beautiful...Puzzle.  Adieu, mes amis.
Loved this puzzle. Friday, Saturday puzzles are delivering week after week.

Anyone else fall for the misdirect at 26-Down?
I  had rENt for "Not own" for the longest time (even thought I thought that was too easy for a Saturday), wondering how the answer at 37-Across could end -TLt, but thinking that, since this is a Saturday, anything is possible.

When I corrected to DENY the puzzle went pretty smoothly.
(Any complaints about the overlap with "Dostoevsky's DENial"?  Not really.)
Oh, I also thought that the "Base of a pump" might be a hOLE, but that corrected itself quickly.

Loved the "Part of a cold pack?" clue!
A satisfying Saturday.

Thanks, Ryan Judge.  Congratulations on your graduation, and best wishes on the transition to the next phase of your life story!
Loved the cluing. Made me smile. I fell for every misdirect. Fun puzzle, solved what k didn‚Äôt know on the crosses.
As usual, I am running against the grain! KIMSCONVENIENCE was my first substantial fill -- I saw the stage play before it became a TV show. Cried like a baby.

When that last letter went in and I didn't get an error message, boy was I surprised! Some fill-ins were a mystery to me at that point. For 'Miami is in it, for short' first I went with MDC, for Miami-Dade County, having no idea it was a sports related clue, and ended up with the correct ACC, not knowing what that stood for until I read the comments. Sports clues are my nemesis, especially athlete names. You either know them, or you don't. My dad followed every sport, college and professional basketball and football, baseball, golf and even bowling, (remember when that was on TV?? lol) so some long buried memory might eventually work its way to the surface about older sports stars and teams, but other than that, sports are totally off my radar and have been for a long time. I appreciate the rare puzzle that has NO sports, but I get that's a huge part of our culture. Have a good Saturday everyone, and you Weekend Warriors, don't forget to warm up!

After about the twelfth pass, sorry, I had to take this as an education, which how I approach all crossword puzzles. I liked it, with lots of help, thank you to Caitlin.

Scale range is not an octave? The heresy! On which scale is a toten?

Edvard‚Äôs name, swapped the vowels, and voila!... still‚Ä¶ nothing.

Fresh off the boat just HAD to fit, didn't it, thinking the constructor had it wrong (they never do). Perhaps my secret crush on Constance Woo?

My violin teacher Miss Klomburg, probably named a frog at some point, but‚Ä¶ nothing. She taught me well, but thank goodness now for 6 strings, frets, capos and inlays.

Let's see; wads up, bunches up, day seven‚Ä¶ oh yeah, RIDES! Yeah, that's uncomfortable, and thank you Ryan Judge so much for that visual. That just took me from Constance Woo to Bea Arthur in two seconds‚Ä¶ thanks!

I've spilled the beans a well-deserved time or two, never the tea. Honest.

I guess donations, sinners and alms are still accepted at church?

I can't recall a Sir Eatsalot in Monty Python, chalk that one up.

Avoid Strands spoilers, plz, ere  View All Replies.

Strands #440
‚ÄúShe's got game‚Äù
üí°üîµüü°üîµ
üîµüîµüîµüîµ
üîµ

Not my forte, just had to guess words.

I‚Äôm from Canada. How convenient.

(Cluing was easy today, but still enjoyable.)

After a few passes, I needed to turn on Autocheck. Even then I struggled. I would have to say the cluing was tricky, mis-directing, but I appreciated them after I got them. It's good to keep the mind nimble. Between last week and this week, I'm still wondering if I'm slipping!

Fairly easy Saturday - I hope this doesn't portend another killer Sunday.

Somehow I got through this quickly despite the clearly excessive mystery sports content. (I don't know sports.)

It helped that I'd somehow heard the name of, though never seen nor heard even a clip or still photo of or article about, Kim's Convenience.

Nice ride overall.
Ironically, Cupid's aro.
STL was my downfall. Not a sports fan at all so idk ARI , but when I SLIMED and DIAL‚Äôed, I heard the happy music.

Back in the 1980's we were FLYINGSOUTH for a trip to a (then) small town in Sao Paulo State in Brazil for a wedding and was told by the family there that we were booked into the Sheraton.  I was puzzled because I could not find that particular location on the list of that chain's worldwide holdings.  

We arrived and discovered that we were staying at the Hotel Shelton.  Still had a lot of fun.  

A workmanlike solve but with a few smiles (FROG, LINEDANCE and DENY).  Many thanks.

Jeezo.
A thoroughly solver-belligerent grid for me today. I developed the hysterical giggles as each impenetrable cutural reference followed the last.
I eventually turned on Autocheck because the guessing game had transitioned from fun, through irksome, to downright infuriating.

On the upside, KIMSCONVENIENCE was a gimme, which gave me a good toehold at the start.

Great cluing and a nice Saturday think for me. I'm happy with sub-15 min. 
LOVED "NFL team whose name is a literary reference". 
It's GHASTLY when your underwear RIDESUP.
TIL - KIMSCONVENIENCE. Got it all through the crosses.
I've got bread rising - come over for a piece this afternnon. We can SPILLTHETEA even if it's mostly HOTAIR.

The versatile FROG.

Even apart from the amphibians and today's bow frog, those pesky frogs get everywhere:

A dent in the face of a brick
The horny concavity in the middle of a horse's hoof
A swelling under the tongue
Oral candidiasis, also called "thrush"
A special piece of grooved track at the point where railway lines cross
The belt loop to which a sword or bayonet can be attached
The decorative fastening of a military coat or jacket

And of course a bunch of stock phrases, metaphorical uses and terms of abuse ...

I loved KIM'S CONVENIENCE. I watched the whole series after enjoying Simu Liu in "Shang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings" (one of my favorite films in the MCU) and looking to see what else he'd starred in.

Pete ALONSO? SRSLY? Yeah, I haven't watched much baseball lately, and if I have, it's strictly American League. (Orioles) So I'm here to lobby for Fernando ALONSO, the legendary Formula 1 driver, who won the drivers' championship twice, and is still racing today. (I'm watching qualifying right now.) At least some of our overseas solvers might know him.

At least TULANE was not clued with Green Wave.

Tough but fair.... for a Saturday.

I'm one Canadian who hasn't heard of KIMS CONVENIENCE, but it sounds like it's a good show... I'll have to look it up. Luckily it wasn't too difficult to guess with a few crosses.

Fun puzzle with just enough bite. There were plenty of things I didn‚Äôt know, but everything was fair and doable. I never thought about where the RAVENS name came from. Congrats on your 4th NYT puzzle, and especially on graduation, Ryan!

I'm happy for Ryan, but unlike other solvers, I had a hard time with this one.  My sports savvy is  limited, I have never eaten a Chicken Nugget, and my initial fills led me far astray.  

"Mescal source" was not "cacti"
 
"Part of a cold pack?" was not "sled dog," which was too bad, because I thought it was one of the most ingenious clues I'd seen for a long time.
Loved this puzzle!  Ingenious and witty clues.  Congrats on graduating and a nod and wink to your hat tip to the Polar Bear!  LGFM!

Worthy Saturday. A lot of misdirects that made me laugh when I figured them out. 

Congratulations, Ryan!

One of the best Saturday Puzzles I‚Äôve dealt with in a while. The ‚Äòthemeless‚Äô theme let Ryan go every which way. Most of the clues were not intentionally misleading, with rigor befitting any puzzle offered on a rainy weekend. Now, I know that not just every good shoe deserves a sole. Bravo!

This was very smooth sailing for me, kind of quick for a Saturday. I wouldn't say it was too easy, just that it had a lot of answers I happened to know right off the bat. Some very clever clues here, too.  I was pleasantly surprised to see a favorite show of mine, KIM'S CONVENIENCE, make an appearance. Sneak attack! Thanks for the fun!
I loved! Kim‚Äôs Convenience is a favorite of mine, and SAMEDAYDELIVERY came to me right away. The sportsball references threw me for a bit, especially in the NE but things worked out in good time!

While long objects can certainly be said to have two ends, to a string player, the only 'end' of the bow is its tip. The frog, held in the hand, is the start of the bow, not 'one end'. If you are going to give that a pass, think of the 'end of a sword'. That would be a poor clue for its hilt.
Lots of little delights, like when I caught on to what 26D "Not own," really was instead of RENT. The E and N had served me well anyway.

We did this in roughly half of our Saturday average. The grandsons called out DINO in unison and the Korean DiL was raised in a CONVENIENCE store and took violin lessons for years. Something for everyone!

This one was right up my alley... So many long gimmes without needing any crosses: 6D BANANA SPLIT came first with no crosses. Others with no or very few crosses: 17A KIMS CONVENIENCE (which  was recommended to me in a Schitt's Creek subreddit a few years ago), RED GIANT, SPILL THE TEA. TEES brings to mind a photo of my brother playing tee ball in the 70s.

For others, I was on the right track but needed more crosses to get the exact phrase: was pretty sure 3D had something to do with Amazon, 11D had to be a convenience store at a gas station (was that subliminally suggested by 17A?), 41D was probably something you use or take for a cold, and 36A had something to do with a wedgie. (Very surprised and delighted no one's complained about the impropriety of that one, or maybe I just haven't seen it.)

I even reasoned out some sports references. ASTROS are from Houston, right? A star and an H make sense. The RAVENS are obviously named for POE. That one should have been a straight gimme because I do live in Maryland, but it wasn't a gimme because sports.

The stickiest section was NE. Fell for rENt instead of DENY and had no idea about the Nickelodeon reference. I think the L in SLIMED was the last to fall after running the alphabet. Made sense and made me laugh.
Curious what diagonal symmetry is referring to?
I was stuck on Prime Choice being SAMEDAYDELIMEAT for the longest time. Eventually, I prevailed.

MEGA STORE yesterday and MINI MART today.

Are there any medium-size retail places left?
Retail seems to have devolved to tat and tatters.

But at least, our crossword puzzles still offer plenty of choices and fresh fill.
thanks, Ryan!
Someone please explain the answer to 56D ‚ÄúBase of a pump‚Äù thank you
My streak has suddenly been reduced from 90 to 18 despite having all gold stars going back to February. Any advice?

Easier than the usual Saturday for me, because I like Sports Ball.

 Still plenty of meat to chew on

My wife lived in Shelton Hall at BU for four years when it was still a women's residence hall, so I was familiar with its earlier incarnation as a Sheraton hotel. Because men were never allowed above the first floor in those days, I never saw more than the lobby. By the 1960s, it had lost whatever charm it may have had when Eugene O'Neill lived (and died) there, but the stories were still told.  Thanks to Ryan Judge and to Caitlin Lovinger for tickling that memory today.

I imagine that for those who knew Kim's store, this puzzle was a lot easier than it was for those who didn't, like me.

I enjoyed the very difficult misdirects, and while they were a struggle, the aha moments made it all worth it.

However, I could have done with fewer proper nouns, titles, labels, definitional terms, etc.

I almost used check puzzle near the end (well 20 minutes before the end), but I soldiered on, hearing the various voices of encouragement that one encounters here.

But dang, 1h 33m to completion, and I had to run the alphabet on the last letter in composer Edvard's surname.

Although this was a gimme for Canadians, I wondered about how others would find it. However, I think the very detailed clue gave everyone plenty to figure it out.

@spurious 
I‚Äôm going to argue the other side of this issue to make a point about clues that look like trivia on their face but can also be considered tests of general background knowledge and logical inference. Sitcoms about family-owned small businesses are common and often feature a business name, like ‚ÄúCheers‚Äù or ‚ÄúBob‚Äôs Burgers.‚Äù The clue‚Äôs use of the term corner store, which is a little uncommon, suggests the deliberate avoidance of a more common synonym. There are a few of these, like mini-mart (used elsewhere in the puzzle) or bodega (but this is in Canada, not New York). Convenience store is such a synonym, one widely used throughout the English-speaking world. I wouldn‚Äôt have guessed it without crossings, but the clues providing the C and the V were fair and after that CONVENIENCE jumped out. That left four letters, with a good chance of being a name, possibly a possessive. We know the family is Korean, which has a small set of surnames, the most common being Kim, which is often in the news. KIM‚ÄôS CONVENIENCE offers the charm of alliteration. Crossings confirm it. I know this is long, but I offer it only as an example of something I see all the time, apparent trivia that offers a fighting chance even when one lacks particular knowledge. A smattering of general knowledge, broad but shallow, can carry the day. Being old helps. And it seems to me that the constructors and editors are sensitive to accusations of too much trivia and try not to be tricky with these.

@Paul Turner

Very good mini lesson in crossword solving 201.

Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

@Mean Old Lady

The St. Louis Cardinals of the NFL moved to ARIzona and took the name with them.

The St. Louis Cardinals of MLB are still there in St. Louis, causing pain to their fans (as all teams do, at least occasionally).

Why the city of St. Louis should be associated with red birds and Catholic dignitaries is a matter for another post.

As the "Perfectos", the team wore their jersey with a cardinal red trim and sock striping. Later that season, St. Louis Republic sportswriter Willie McHale included an account in a column of a female fan he heard remarking about the uniforms, "What a lovely shade of cardinal." Fans liked the moniker "Cardinals" and, the next year in 1900, popularity for the nickname induced an official change to Cardinals. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._Louis_Cardinals

@Mean Old Lady

The St. Louis Cardinals baseball team has been around a long time, in St. Louis from the start, and known as the Cardinals since 1900. 

The Arizona Cardinals football team moved to the Phoenix area from St. Louis in 1988, but it was mere coincidence that prior to that, St. Louis had two different teams called the Cardinals. The football Cardinals were originally from Chicago, where they were called the Cardinals since 1901, almost 20 years before the establishment of the NFL. 

The football Cardinals were actually in Chicago almost twice as long as they were in St. Louis under that name.  And they have now been in Arizona longer than they were in St, Louis. 

The name of both the football and baseball teams derive from the color of their uniform; the connection to birds came later. 

On a different note: one rock group? Really? Never heard of the Beatles? The Rolling Stones?
@The X-Phile well the name is a saint, after all!  And there are a bunch of seminaries and convents there so ‚Ä¶ as for the red bird, don‚Äôt know.

@Mean Old Lady

From Wikipedia: ‚ÄúThe oldest established team in the NFL is the Arizona Cardinals, founded in 1898 as the Morgan Athletic Club. They joined the NFL in its founding year of 1920. The Cardinals have moved locations multiple times, starting in Chicago, then to St. Louis, and finally settling in Phoenix.‚Äù

@Nancy J.

Some of us who know a thing or two about sports also put in AfC for 12-Down, knowing that  the "Miami" Dolphins are in  the East Division of the American Football Conference.

The AFC came into existence when the AFL merged with the NFL in 1966.

College sports conferences, on the other hand, have become a huge mess.  Just ask a sports lover "How many teams are in the Big Ten?"  The Big Ten is not to be confused with the Big 12, which currently has 16 teams, and that's after its best teams left for the SEC.

The University of Miami joined the ACC (the Atlantic Coast Conference) in 2004, fleeing the Big East.

@Elke
This construction turns up in puzzles from time to time, as sports scoreboards tend to have the first three letters of the team's location, not the abbreviations we use in real life. Hence ARI for Arizona, not AZ.

@Jane Wheelaghan
DEN is a common term (in NA) for a room in the house that is more casual than a living room and usually has the TV, stereo, games etc. Not every house has both, of course, in which case the den would be a place to both entertain guests and relax with family.

The symmetry lies about a line drawn from the upmost left box to the lowest right box. If you fold the puzzle on that line, the pattern overlaps. Traditionally, puzzles are symmetric around the center square; if you rotate the pattern 180¬∞ around the pattern the pattern remains the same.
